column4: hello all.  How do I set my domain?  That is, my host is called "bianca", and has dns name bianca.example.com;  I want resolving "ariel" to resolve ariel.example.com
(addresses are assign via dhcp; I don't control the dhcp server)
is that resolving done on the net, or is it local?
non-local
/etc/hosts work for local resolution, for internet you'd have to set up dns 'out there'
the dns is set up
what I want is to type "ariel" instead of "ariel.example.com", when I'm on bianca
ah, add xx.xx.xx.xx in /etc/hosts on bianca to point at ariel
no; the IP address might change
I don't want to update my /etc/hosts file every time I get a new address
then you can't do it locally, you have to set it up externally.
adding "domain example.com" to /etc/resolv.conf seems to work, but only temporarily.  I was wondering how resolv.conf is built...
it's set up by dhcp (I'm assuming you're using dhcp)
also, it contained (on my ubuntu box) a line "search example.org", which must be a holdover from the installation (my ISP wouldn't hand out that domain)...
is this for use with ssh?
this is for use with all dns clients
is ariel on a local net, and it's local ip doesn't change?
no, that's not the case
ah, then that solution won't work
which solution?
back to /etc/hosts, but using a static local ip
